awd_titl_txt: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Mechanics and Dynamics of Low Frequency Vibration Assisted Machining
awd_abstract_narration:
This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project partners two universities with industry in the fundamental research on the effect of applying slow vibrations to enhance material removal in machining processes. Vibrations have been treated as a disturbance and a source of inefficiency to many manufacturing operations including machining processes. However, this new approach attempts to use low frequency (slow) vibrations to improve the contact conditions between the cutting tool and workpiece and thereby improve machining efficiency. By applying controlled slow oscillations to cutting tools, this new cutting process can enable material removal with lower cutting effort and energy, attain longer tool-life, and improve overall stability of the machining process towards higher material removal rates. It can significantly enhance manufacturing productivity, and hence US competitiveness and prosperity, and product quality especially for components made of difficult-to-cut metal alloys employed in U.S. automotive, aerospace, defense and energy sectors. Collaboration with a partner from US automotive industry will help ensure the technology transfer and enhance student training.

This project investigates the mechanisms by which low frequency vibration applied in continuous cutting process can alter and improve the cutting mechanics and dynamics. Modulating the tool at low frequency along tool feed direction transforms continuous cutting into discrete cutting. This new discrete cutting kinematics not only alters the deformation mechanics of chip formation, but also changes the thermomechanical dynamics in the cutting zone as well as the dynamic stability of the machining process. This research will analyze chip formation mechanics through in-situ digital image correlation and develop analytical models to understand the relationship between vibration kinematics, including cutting force and energy, and overall material removal effort. As the low frequency modulation periodically disengages the cutting tool from the workpiece, it interrupts continuous heating of the cutting edge and induces pre-determined cool-down periods to reduce tool temperature. Analytical models and experimental characterization will capture this transient and cyclic heat conduction regime and its thermo-mechanics. It will provide optimal cutting strategies to increase the tool-life. Finally, effect of feed modulation on the coupled dynamics of process and the machining equipment will be investigated. New knowledge will be created on how to use the controlled low frequency vibration to control and suppress high-frequency self-excited chatter instabilities during machining. It will allow machining of precision parts at significantly higher depth, feed and speed leading to greater material removal rates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Manufacturing processes such as milling, turning, drilling, and grinding are fundamental to the metal cutting industries and the backbone of modern manufacturing. This project investigated the effect of a novel idea where controlled (intentional) low-frequency tool oscillations are induced during the machining process to maximize the productivity of the manufacturing operation. The project focused on understanding how such controlled oscillations enhance the metal cutting effort (force, torque, power) used during the operation, how it elongates the life of the cutting tool/insert used, and how it maximizes the stable material removal rates (MRR) to attain greater productivity. The project generated the following scientific knowledge and practical outcomes to impact the modern manufacturing industries broadly:

i) Controlled low-frequency tool oscillations applied during single-point ordinary turning operations convert the  continuous chip generation mechanics of the process into discrete cutting by instantaneously removing the tool from the cut. As a result, the generated chip becomes discrete. Mathematical models are developed to predict the chip formation and its effect on the cutting effort. Such models can be utilized to control the tool oscillations for best performance. In practice, the strategy is highly effective for eliminating the chip-jam for preserving the tool life and facilitating highly automated machining processes for greater productivity.

ii) It is also found that such controlled tool oscillations help reduce the machining temperature. Since the tool is removed from the cut instantaneously, the average tool temperature can be reduced by 10-20%. Furthermore, the peak tool temperature location (hot-spot) can be removed away from the tool tip for elongating the tool life. Mathematical models are developed to predict the temperature distribution along the tool/cutting insert for selecting the optimal tool oscillation profile.

iii) Finally, the effect of tool oscillations on maximizing the material removal rates is investigated. In most machining operations, the attainable maximum MRR is limited by the dynamic stability of the process. Unwanted chatter vibrations occur that harm the equipment when operating high MRRs. It is found that controlled tool modulations can suppress such unwanted (chatter) vibrations and thereby help attain greater MRRs. Mathematical models are developed to predict how controlled tool oscillations improve the dynamic stability of the process and optimize the process parameters for attaining higher MRRs. 

Overall, this project generated new scientific knowledge on how controlled low-frequency tool vibrations improve the productivity of machining operations. The physics of the process is modeled mathematically so that manufacturing engineers can optimize the process parameters for greater productivity. The information generated in this project is disseminated to the manufacturing community through multiple conference presentations, proceedings, and international journal articles.


Last Modified: 11/12/2024
Modified by: Burak Sencer
